   @emkornfield thanks for asking :) I've let this go way too long
   This is supposed to test the use-case described [here](https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/37c0480c4c7a48dd298e8459938444afb901bf01dcebd5f8c5f1dee6@%3Cdev.arrow.apache.org%3E)
   
   This test is designed to fail.. but it's probably worth merging this PR without the `generate` call and create associated JIRAs to fix the places where it fails.

trxcllnt commented on issue #1848: ARROW-2412: [Integration] Add nested dictionary test case
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1848#issuecomment-491417246
 
 
   @TheNeuralBit btw this change looks good to me, but we should probably add some test cases to validate the reader and writer do the correct thing. We may also encounter some unanswered questions in the process. For example, are there requirements/guarantees that dictionary ids are preserved, or is the implementation free to rewrite the ids of dictionaries as necessary?
   
   @wesm I want to double check, how are you thinking about dictionary deltas, and how it relates to variable dictionaries? The JS has deltas implemented as appending new values to an existing dictionary to create a ChunkedArray. I could see someone wanting to replace or partially update a dictionary, or being confused and assuming that's what the `isDelta` flag does, so I want to ensure JS and C++ are in alignment there.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

wesm commented on issue #1848: ARROW-2412: [Integration] Add nested dictionary test case
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1848#issuecomment-491455969
 
 
   @trxcllnt our arrays are immutable, so to avoid breaking immutability, when a delta is observed, the next RecordBatch produced will have a larger dictionary for the corresponding Field. What I'm working on for ARROW-3144 is making the dictionary part of the ArrayData data structure rather than the Schema/type object. You might contemplate doing something similar in JS if the change goes over well in C++ (I'm pretty sure it's the right thing to do...)
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

trxcllnt commented on issue #1848: ARROW-2412: [Integration] Add nested dictionary test case
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1848#issuecomment-491462542
 
 
   @wesm if I recall correctly, the JS implementation did have a special `DictionaryData` subclass of ArrayData, but we eliminated it (and all the other ArrayData subclasses) when we consolidated the functionality into the class we have now, though the `isDelta` flag was an important motivator also.
   
   The Vectors in JS are also immutable, so I really meant we (zero-copy) [concatenate the current dictionary with the delta dictionary](https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/3eb07b7ed173e2ecf41d689b0780dd103df63a00/js/src/ipc/reader.ts#L360) to create a ChunkedArray.
   
   I'm not sure how familiar you are with the JS, and obviously solve this however you need to in CPP, but in case there's ideas worth cross-pollinating, here's a quick description of how we're doing it in JS:
   
   To ensure all Fields that reference the same dictionary id are always pointing at the same Vector instance, we [store added a `dictionaryVector` pointer to the Dictionary DataType](https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/3eb07b7ed173e2ecf41d689b0780dd103df63a00/js/src/type.ts#L491). Since this instance is part of the Schema, it's shared across all current and future RecordBatches. We then updated DictionaryArray to [retrieve the `dictionaryVector`](https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/3eb07b7ed173e2ecf41d689b0780dd103df63a00/js/src/vector/dictionary.ts#L38)  from the shared Dictionary DataType instance, rather than each DictionaryArray having its own pointer to the dictionary.
   
   When the Reader sees new delta DictionaryBatch, it [updates the `dictionaryVector` pointer](https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/3eb07b7ed173e2ecf41d689b0780dd103df63a00/js/src/ipc/reader.ts#L364) on the Dictionary DataType in the Schema.
   
   This approach ensures that all DictionaryArrays point to the same underlying dictionary instance, even if you created the DictionaryArray before the delta batch was processed. This is safe, since DictionaryArrays that already exist before the delta dictionary is parsed by the reader won't have indices that point beyond the original DictionaryBatch. But if you have a pointer to a DictionaryArray that was created before the delta batch came in, calling `oldDictArray.dictionary` is guaranteed to return you the full, most up-to-date version of that Field's underlying dictionary.
   
   Hope this helps, and let me know if we need to discuss further. I don't want the JS to deviate from the C++ behavior here, and am happy to make changes to align the features if necessary.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

issuetype.description: A task that needs to be done.
issuetype.name: Task

fields.description: Add nested dictionary generator to the integration test. The tests will probably fail at first but can serve as a starting point for developing this capability.

comments.body: Marked for 0.11 release cycle so we can investigate
[~bhulette] is there a patch for this?

[~wesmckinn] yes there is a (very outdated) patch: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1848

I never merged it for fear of making the tests fail, but I should probably just add it with the generate call commented out.
We can rebase the patch and return to the issue
